Its message is that 'Life is difficult' and that we make it more so by running away from our responsibilities and pretending that life cannot be difficult. Peck's prescription for a better life is realizing that life involves a constant effort to understand and improve ourselves. He supplies case- histories of people who seem to have given up or be lost, and then in psychotherapy with him find a way to make better lives. One especially moving story was of a young man who simply could not feel joy at anything in life. He simply had lost his enthusiasm. It turned out that not only had this young man lost a best friend, he had grown up in a world where his two elder brothers knocked down immediately any idea he might have. They tormented him continually and made fun of him. And the parents never paid attention. Peck in two years of psychotherapy was able to teach this young person to stop being fixated at what he was when he was ten years old. He taught the young man how to respect his own thoughts.<br /><br />Peck's message again is of a new psychologyof love, traditional values and spiritual growth.He warns against our tendency to escape from freedom, and to rely on outdated maps of our situation.<br /><br />My sense is that this book has helped so many people in part because so many of us need help. We are continually looking for a message, a word of wisdom or spiritual insight that will help us , and renew our faith in ourselves and life. We are continually looking for a spiritual teacher that will be able to help us.<br /><br />I must admit that this book does not really provide me personally with the kind of message and help I feel a need for at the moment.<br /><br />How I miss my teacher and friend the Holy Teacher Dovid Herzberg who taught by his example a love of people and joy in being with them which lifted up all those who knew him.<br /><br />Scott Peck by this book probably helped thousands maybe even tens of thousands of people. B000002LQR|5.0|So yes, we live in a world where rock fans soak up corporate mess and other bands that thrive on attitude but not necessarily good songwriting. In this case, Blood Sugar Sex Magik would be too intelligent of an album for all of you. It's an album that is a complete microcosm filled with musical styles from hardcore funk metal to New Orleans jazz. It is a different sounding sort of rock and there is a reason why this is the summit for anyone that is a true Red Hot Chili Peppers fan.  <br /> <br />Forget Californication and By The Way. This is the album that gave the Red Hot Chili Peppers something they had lacked for a long time before this -- an identity. Gone were the days of wild drug habits, band engimas, fights with producers, and minimal creative control. This is where four creative and ingenuous musicians -- Anthony Kiedis, Flea, John Frusciante, and Chad Smith.  <br /> <br />There are two things worth noting on this album. Every track was recorded live and was not overdubbed or anything -- you can hear Rick Rubin's voice before \\"The Power of Equality\\" and \\"Suck My Kiss\\" and the crickets chirping at the end of \\"Sir Pyscho Sexy\\" and \\"They're Red Hot\\". In other words, this is how the album was intended to sound without the remastering or anything. The dirt is right there and it makes you feel like you are actually in the studio with them recording these songs in the summer of 1991. Another thing is, each band member wrote their own part of their song, so the creativity behind each of the songs is stronger and the songs sounding more pure. <br /> <br />They always say Anthony Kiedis's lyrics are unintelligent. I highly dispute that...drugs, globalization, sex, life, relationships, attitude, humanity, war, politics, peace, human rights...all of that is discussed in this album. So you tell me if Kiedis cannot write unintelligent lyrics. I don't think unintelligent lyrics are supposed to make you think. <br /> <br />As for the songs, there are absolutely no fillersin this album unlike their later albums. In fact, this is the last album that would not contain fillers in my opinion. It starts off with  <br /> <br />\\"The Power of Equality\\" a politically charged high energy song with Kiedis doing very impressive rapping and Flea delivering a top notch bassline.  <br /> <br />\\"If You Had To Ask\\" is a humorous song about Kiedis's life in L.A.  <br /> <br />\\"Breaking The Girl\\" , which is about broken relationships, is a type of song where their funk meets classical music in a way.  <br /> <br />\\"Funky Monks\\", is a song about every man and woman out there, including themselves. I could not believe John could actually sing that high on chorus, and Flea's suging bassline is the best bassline you will ever hear besides the following song.  <br /> <br />\\"Suck My Kiss\\" is an ode to sex and society and it is impressive how Flea and John combine their instruments to create one sound.  <br /> <br />\\"I Could Have Lied\\" is pretty much the saddest song you will ever hear as it also touches on broken relationships.  <br /> <br />\\"Mellowship Slinky in B Major\\" is all about Kiedis's life as it is very lighthearted and provides a very heavy funked up guitar riff by John.  <br /> <br />\\"The Righteous & The Wicked\\" is another politically charged song as it refers to the Gulf War. John's guitar work is impressive here. Kiedis' vocals add to the dynamics of the song.  <br /> <br />\\"Give It Away\\" is their first number one hit and also amongst the best on this album. The juice harp was pretty well pared with John's guitar and Flea provides a very very addictive bassline. Chad's drumming also helps move the song along pretty well. <br /> <br />\\"Blood Sugar Sex Magik\\" might be their weakest song on the album, but nonetheless still a quality listen. Very erotic guitar by John. Great drumming by Chad. <br /> <br />\\"Under The Bridge\\" is about Anthony's heroin stage forshadows the way they would do ballads for here on out. Comes as a stand still on the album and it is pretty good. Amazingly nearly did not make the album due the fact Anthony originally stashed the lyrics away and Soul To Squeeze was going to be put on here. <br /> <br />\\"Naked In The Rain\\" is pretty much about society and escaping to a utopia. Not one of the more popular RHCP song, it still deserves to be on the album and it is pretty good. Nice bassline by Flea. <br /> <br />\\"Apache Rose Peacock\\" is by far the funkiest and the best song on the album. Being about a girl Anthony saw in New Orleans creatively and allegorically referred to as the apache rose peacock, it features very addictive bassline by Flea and Anthony's random lyrics make it the party on the album. <br /> <br />\\"The Greeting Song\\" is amongst the fastest songs RHCP ever made. A very surging and refreshing ride from start to finish. <br /> <br />\\"My Lovely Man\\" is the ode to Hillel Slovak and features a tearjerking melodical bass play by Flea, followed by as surging solo by John. <br /> <br />\\"Sir Pyscho Sexy\\" is pretty much the dirtiest 5 1/2 minutes you'll ever hear followed by the sweetest 2 1/2 minute instrumental RHCP has ever done. It was to be the original closing to the album. <br /> <br />\\"They're Red Hot\\" was a goof off recorded at 2 AM on the hill outside the mansion they recorded the album. It serves as a funny way to end the album, almost like an throw in scene long after the end of a play. Pretty good. Features Chad playing with only his hands. <br /> <br />It's a great album, I love it, it means the world to me and you should get this album to really know how a real band creates music and creates an album.

Heck, plenty of people lose a loved one in violent fashion, but what would make a man punish himself to become what Bruce became? Even with great wealth, that isn't easy. Once again, it is proven that even in a superhero movie, a good story well told is worth more than a billion in special effects. We're introduced to many characters that comics fans know and love, Morgan Freeman as Lucious Fox, Liam Neesom as Henri Ducard are two that I suspect will be recurring characters, and Gary Oldman absolutely nails a young Jim Gordon, a character that was totally neglected in the previous Batman movies. <br /> <br />Not only was this a great movie, it sets up the sequels (yes, plural) in a big way.

B00005JOGU|5.0|I caught a sneak preview of Capote at the ArcLight earlier this evening and I have to say: Dammmmnnnnnn!<br /><br />Capote is based on the true story of how Truman Capote, one of America's legendary writers, came to write his masterpiece non-fiction, In Cold Blood--an account on a mass murder that took place in Kansas City on November 15, 1959. The film concentrates on Capote's interaction with the lead killer through the meetings he managed to arrange for them in jail. It explorers how researching the murder affected Capote and changed him forever.<br /><br />The film is remarkable! It captures the late '50s and early '60s impeccably with flawless set dressing and imposed film grain. Capote's interesting life was touched upon with certain aspects highlighted such as his friendship with Harper Lee--author of literary classic To Kill a Mockingbird--and his effiminacy.<br /><br />Philip Seymor Huffman should win an Oscar for his outstanding performance as Truman Capote. His accent, posture, gestures and most subtle inflections were perfection. He definitely delivered the best performance by an actor in a leading role this year thus far.<br /><br />Everyone should see this film! It's a terrific story with stellar performances. It doesn't get better than this.

B0009WFFS6|5.0|I was at the Cream concert on Friday 6th May, at which 14 of the 19 numbers on this DVD were filmed, and can confirm that it's a pretty flawless record of the night - sounds the same, looks the same & brilliantly shot - which is just about all you can ask from any DVD of a rock concert.     And how good was it? Just stunning... not only better than you could hope any reunion of Cream could be but one of the best live concerts I've ever seen. Friday was clearly the night to be there - Eric Clapton describes it as the \\"consummate gig\\" in the interviews on the DVD - and it shows. The playing and singing are exceptional and Ginger Baker's drumming is, for a man of 65, quite unbelievable. I was lucky enough to see them play a couple of times in 1966 & 1967 when they were \\"at the peak of their powers\\" and at their farewell concert in 1968, which was a great disappointment, and believe me they didn't play like this. Tight, exciting, powerful and, above all, infused with sheer enthusiasm this is live music at it should be, captured as it was. Forty years on it's quite simply Cream at their very best.

6305075492|5.0|This film, as is understood by anybody who takes even a second to research it, is basically the height of German Expressionism.  It is the base of the psyche, an insanity so removed one begins to wonder if the movie is about insanity or if the makers were just insane.<br /><br />A man tells his friend about the story of Dr. Caligari, a demented stranger who enters his town during a carnival with a somnambulist who can divinate the future.  The story traces a murder mystery that treads down contemporarily familiar paths, but the sheer audacity of the sets, costuming, music, and acting makes every moment unpredictable and confusing.<br /><br />The only problem with this German silent great is that a few of the absolutely astounding sets are obviously stages.  Otherwise this movie is perfect.<br /><br />And creepy.  Boy is it creepy.  The characters don't even look real in their shapes and contortions sometimes, more like ventriloquist dummies or marionettes, though who would ever make such marionettes would probably need to be hospitalized.  The music itself is so creepy it could honestly stand alone without the image and some wouldn't even tell the difference.  Actually, it's mostly through the music that we're able to even comprehend what's going on, such is the twisted reality of the world we see.<br /><br />This movie is right on the edge, and it seems any more added to it would have made it topple over.  It's its own fine line between the abyss and security.  A must for fans of the absyrd.<br /><br />--PolarisDiB

0740748475|5.0|The strip in question is from 25 November 1988.  The original dialogue goes like this: <br /> <br />CALVIN: Watch out, Mom. I'm in a bad mood. <br />MOM: Be in a bad mood somewhere else, OK? I'm busy. <br />CALVIN: Hmph! I'll bet my biological mother would've bought me a comic book and made me feel better instead of shunning me like you. <br />MOM: Kid, anyone but your biological mother would've left you to the wolves long ago. <br />CALVIN: Yeah right. Really, how much did you pay for me? <br /> <br />In the Complete C&H, however, the phrase 'my/your biological mother' is changed to 'a good mother,' and Calvin's final bit of dialogue has been altered to: 'Yeah, right. Let's see your training certificate.' <br /> <br />Since Bill Watterson exercises strict control over the strip, clearly the edit was his.  Why?  I don't know, but I can make a pretty good guess: The original language is insensitive to adoptive families.  It implies that biological parents/children have a bond that adoptive parents/children don't.   <br /> <br />Why would this matter to Bill?  Maybe he's got friends who adopted, or maybe he did.  Look at the dedications in the book.  The last dedication made by Bill is to his wife and .... who?  <br />Bill is 47 now.  He didn't have a kid when the strip was running, even though he was married.  Perhaps he and his wife adopted.

B00005JO0J|5.0|Do you remember the first time you saw \\"Star Wars?\\" How'd you feel afterwards? Like George Lucas had been following you around, making notes about what you read, what you watched, what you loved? Like he'd interviewed your friends, your relatives, checked with Santa about your Christmas wish lists? Do you remember how many people you dragged back to the theatre, over and over, converting all your friends like some demented Jedi missionary? Do you remember how you waited for \\"Return of the Jedi\\", how you wrote letters about how it shouldn't be named \\"Revenge of the Jedi\\" and you stood in line for tickets for 3 days? How long's it been since you felt that way? Yeah, you're in your 40's now, you've got a 40-hour-a-week job that you spend 70 hours a week doin', your wife wants you to wallpaper the bathroom, your kids are away at college buying I-Pods with their book money, it just cost you $70 to have your dog's teeth cleaned and all you wanna do is feel like you did back then.    Well, this is your lucky day, my friend; you have a chance to relive that experience. Joss Whedon has brought you an early Christmas present called \\"Serenity.\\" You've heard of Joss; \\"Buffy, the Vampire Slayer,\\" \\"Angel\\" and a little series on Fox called \\"Firefly.\\" That last was a special kind of show; great writing, a tight cast, a haunting score and a story line that made all the other sc-fi you'd seen lately seem like episodes of \\"Meet the Press.\\" Fox did their best to kill it; they refused to show the pilot, they showed episodes out of order, they pre-empted it and then abandoned it with 3 episodes left unaired. Like 40 or 50 other Fox shows in recent years, it was dead.    But it wasn't dead. The fans, Browncoats, as they call themselves, immediately started writing letters, making phone calls, posting messages on sc-fi web sites and blogs, all in an effort to save the show. That, and Joss wouldn't quit. He told the cast they were cancelled and, almost in the same breath, told them not togive up, that he'd find them a home. Together they made enough noise that Fox decided to release the series on DVD, figuring that'd shut the fans up and they could go back to putting quality shows on the air like \\"The Simple Life.\\" But, then, DVD sales just took off. Word spread, mostly fan to fan. People began having DVD viewing parties, buying DVDs for friends, setting up booths at sci-fi conventions to promote the show and the DVDs with no help from Fox. You see, they loved the show and it's characters and the folks who gave them life so much that they were willing to do the promotion Fox wouldn't spring for. And, they made enough noise (and bought enough DVDs) that they got the attention of Universal Studios who, perhaps remembering Star Trek and the above mentioned Star Wars, decided to spring $40,000,000 for a movie.    It was money well spent. \\"Serenity\\" is everything the series and the above mentioned franchises were, and much more. Mr. Whedon, being simply the most eloquent script writer on the planet, has given the film a story line that not only satisfies (at least, temporarily) the Fireflyistas, it's a knock down, kick butt film in it's own right.    The plot: Five hundred years in the future, Earth has become uninhabitable, and the human race has moved on to a new solar system made up of dozens of terraformed planets. There is a bloody civil war between the government of the inner core of planets, known as the Alliance, and a rag-tag collaboration of independents, who populated the outer planets and call themselves Browncoats. The Alliance, of course, prevails. A few years later Malcom Reynolds (Nathan Fillion), a veteran of the losing side, scrapes by as the captain of a Firefly-class ship, Serenity, named after the location of the battle which ended the war. With a crew comprised of the only other survivor of Reynolds' platoon, Zoe (Gina Torres), a wise cracking pilot and Zoe's husband, Wash (Alan Tudyk), a young tomboy mechanic, Kaylee (Jewel Staite)and a mercenary who would sell out his mother to the highest bidder, Jayne (Adam Baldwin), Mal takes any job, legal or not, particularly if he can stick it to the Alliance in the process. When they take on two passengers, a young doctor and his sister, they get more than they bargained for. The doctor, Simon (Sean Maher), rescued his sister, River (Summer Glau), a psychic, from an Alliance research facility where she was the subject of experiments aimed toward...well, we're still not quite sure. River, still recovering from her experience, is being pursued by a ruthless Operative (Chiwetel Ejiofor), sent by the Alliance to retrieve their \\"property\\".    In the hands of another writer or director this could easily have deteriorated into one of those horrible, clichd Sci-Fi Channel movie-of-the-week monstrosities (You know, the ones that always seem to star David Keith or the latest hunk from some WB network teen drama) or a low budget throwaway designed to ride the coat tails of the latest chapter of the \\"Star Wars\\" franchise (Think \\"Spacehunter: Adventures In The Forbidden Zone\\"). But an excellent script and a cast that have to rely on talent rather than name recognition make this movie so much more than the sum of it's parts. The film is built on story and subtle attention to detail, it doesn't rely on over-the-top special effects or unstoppable blood-sucking aliens. (In Joss's vision of the future, the monsters are all too human.)    It's to Mr. Whedon's credit that this film is able to stand on it's own as a truly great example of the genre, not just as an addendum to an abandoned television series. See it now. You'll laugh, you'll cry, you'll cheer, you'll tell your friends and drag 'em to the theatre and wait in line three days for the sequel. You'll regain your youth. And the next coat you buy just might be a bit brown...

It chronicled all their European hits from 1981 to 1991. How does it hold up read on?<br /><br />Positives:<br /><br />-If you're only a fan of Queen's later work, than this collection is ideal. In my opinion, the outro solo is John Petrucci's best EVER.  Amazing. <br />Rating: A+ <br /> <br />Overall, I highly suggest this album to any prog fan, a great album.
B000000W5L|5.0|I ignored this record when it was released back in 72.  I can't really say why other than the bad boy image was annoying.  I had no interest in this band.  Anyway, a couple of weeks ago I started thinking about this record after seeing some brokerage advertising with the Stones on stage.  I looked over the reviews here and the review below \\"A Place, not a CD\\" convinced me to pick this up.  That reviewer is absolutely correct and I'm not going to wax on (no pun intended) about every detail of this record.  This is a \\"beefy stew\\" of deep blues ala John Lee Hooker, Muddy Waters, Skip James, Robert Johnson, the voodoo of Dr John, gospel, \\"red-neck\\" rock and real country music.  For those familiar with the music of Tom Waits, it would be hard to believe his works such as Swordfish Trombone and Rain Dogs were not at least partially influenced by this record (listen to \\"Just Want to See His Face\\" and try not to think of Tom Waits)<br /><br />Every track is a treasure - no tempation to hit the skip button on the player whatsoever. There are no hits here other than Tumbling Dice and Happy. Somehow I doubt these charted all that well back in the day...  Who cares?<br /><br />I have one small but meaningful criticism of this record.  The producer Jimmy Miller blew it.  This is such an authentic piece of Americana, raunchy country-folk-blues that the studio fades at the end of each song are somewhat annoying (or disappointing).  They should have put a proper finish on each tune to add to its authentic down home sound.  That's a small gripe given how truly great this CD is.  I can live with it.<br /><br />I really love this record and I'm glad I purchased it.  Buy it, but don't expect hit single type material. It's way better than a bunch of attempts at hit singles.<br /><br />POSTSCRIPT:  3 weeks later - I can't get the darn thing out of my CD Player!  I can't stop playing it!  I LOVE this CD!  And I'm not even a Stones fan!<br /><br />POSTSCRIPT:  3 Months later - It is still getting heavy rotation and it was this release that drove me to start snatching up the Stones remasters. This really is THAT good. It is worthy of every syllable of hype you may have heard.  If you've read any of my other reviews, you know that I am reticent to call anything \\"the greatest\\" and I hesitate to do so now; however, I am going to go out on a limb and proclaim this to be one of maybe 1/2 dozen of the very best releases of the 70's decade.  I really don't think that's a stretch at all.  No wonder the subsequent releases such as Goats Head Soup fail to provide as much satisfaction.  You want satisfaction?  Pick up Exile on Main Street.  By the way, I have since learned that Tom Waits has a celebrity top 10 list here on Amazon.com.  Exile on Mainstreet is #4 on his list :) Fabulous, simply fabulous.<br /><br />Four Months Later:  Still getting heavy rotation along with Johnny Winter And Live and Mayall's Bluesbreakers with Clapton. Exile is probably one of the 5 best recordings I have purchased since 1967 - no foolin'.  Anyone who calls this \\"over-rated\\" is just musically ignorant.<br /><br />About a Year Later:  Not as much rotation but still consider this to be one of the best CDs in my collection and definitely the best thing the Stones ever laid down on tape.release that drove me to start snatching up the Stones remasters. This really is THAT good. It is worthy of every syllable of hype you may have heard.  If you've read any of my other reviews, you know that I am reticent to call anything \\"the greatest\\" and I hesitate to do so now; however, I am going to go out on a limb and proclaim this to be one of maybe 1/2 dozen of the very best releases of the 70's decade.  I really don't think that's a stretch at all.  No wonder the subsequent releases such as Goats Head Soup fail to provide as much satisfaction.  You want satisfaction?  Pick up Exile on Main Street.  By the way, I have since learned that Tom Waits has a celebrity top 10 list here on Amazon.com.  Exile on Mainstreet is #4 on his list :) Fabulous, simply fabulous.    Four Months Later:  Still getting heavy rotation along with Johnny Winter And Live and Mayall's Bluesbreakers with Clapton. Exile is probably one of the 5 best recordings I have purchased since 1967 - no foolin'.  Anyone who calls this \\"over-rated\\" is just musically ignorant.    About a Year Later:  Not as much rotation but still consider this to be one of the best CDs in my collection and definitely the best thing the Stones ever laid down on tape.
B0007XT7V8|4.0|In the 3 years it took for theory of a deadman to complete and release \\"gasoline\\" (their follow-up to \\"theory of a deadman\\"), you'd think the band would have gone through some musical changes. Well, they did, and they didn't. With \\"self-titled\\", it was hard to argue the blatant similarities to nickelback, both musically and lyrically. I personally remember thinking that it was almost as if Chad and the boys were channeling their sound through theory. Don't get we wrong now, I still think it's their best release to date, but it was refreshing to hear theory come to their own on \\"gasoline\\". While this record still carries the radio-rock formula that made nickelback and co. so famous, it has other, different elements to it as well. More acoustic songs, strings and even some country-rock tracks set \\"gasoline\\" apart from it's peers. Produced by Howard Benson (hoobastank, cold, P.O.D), \\"gasoline\\" has a more pop-friendly sound than it's former, and could easily get play on top 40 FM.     The album opens up with two strong tracks called \\"Hating Hollywood\\" and \\"no way out\\", with the second being about religion, something new for theory. Although theory themselves have never openly admitted to being religious or not, you can pretty much determine their faith through the lyrics; \\"your god ain't much of a know it all\\".       Things move right along with the band's first single \\"no surprise\\", a country rock song with a pop-friendly chorus. \\"Quiver\\" is another solid track, which is here and gone in under 3 minutes, and sets the tone well for \\"Santa Monica\\", the album's highlight acoustic song. Although many fans claim this track to be their favorite, I'd have to say I'm more partial to the later songs.     Half way through we have \\"better off\\" and \\"say goodbye\\". \\"better off\\" isn't really the greatest song ever written, but it does have a good chorus and some catchy riffing. \\"say goodbye\\" follows the same formula as \\"the last song\\" (see \\"theory of a deadman\\" track 7), with a complicated  acoustic intro and a huge, dynamic sound.       \\"Hello lonely\\" is my personal favorite on the record. Here, Tyler's vocals seem to shine the brightest, and there's no denying that his song writing has never been better. \\"me and my girl\\" brings the album back to it's hard rock sound, with a nu-metal like intro and a soaring chorus.  This could be the heaviest theory song ever recorded, keeping in mind that theory was never that heavy to begin with.     The last four songs are a real mixed bag. \\"since you've been gone\\" and \\"in the middle\\" rank as second and third place favorites behind \\"hello lonely\\". I can't say the same for the other two. Honestly, I don't think I would have cried if \\"save the best for last\\" wasn't included, and \\"hell just ain't the same\\" proves that even major label acts still like to include a filler here and there. Luckily, these tracks fall right in between two of the best ones, so you can easily listen to the record all the way through.     I guess it goes without saying that if you're not a fan of nickelback, or radio-rock in general, theory of a deadman's \\"gasoline\\" won't be high on your list of favorites. However, if you're a fan of bands like 3 doors down, hoobastank and of course, nickelback, give these guys a shot. They might just turn into your new favorite band. Although I personally enjoyed the debut more, \\"gasoline\\" is a more commercially appealing release, and a perfect place to start if you're new to the band.  I look forward to hearing more from theory in the future, and hopefully next time around they'll experiment even more and give us an altogether different sound.
B0000AQS0F|5.0|When I first heard about Firefly I thought, What? A space-western?  But by the time I had seen 2 episodes I was lamenting the fact that there were only 12 more to watch.  The cast is amazing, each playing there roles flawlessly, each so straightforward and yet having unplumbed depths. There was so much potential in this series, so many tales that beg to be told, but Fox killed that all.  I never even heard of Firefly while it was on TV, but now it is the first TV series that I have bought on DVD.  I even saw the movie.  Both it and this are totally worth your money!
B000AL730Y|5.0|Con ms de 40 aos de vida artstica, y con todos los logros y xitos obtenidos,  a estas alturas, haga lo que haga Sir Macca, lo puede hacer sabiendo que  no tiene nada que perder ni nada que lisonjear, pero como ya es costumbre en l, siempre se las ingenia para sorprendernos dentro de su convencionalismo, mostrarse vigente y con muchas ideas creativas.    Chaos And Creation es el primero en estudio desde el Driving Rain (2001), en el cual toca la mayora de los instrumentos  de cuerda, vientos, teclados y percusin; de los trece temas, cuatro de ellos son ejecutados totalmente por l, tan igual como lo hiciera en McCartney I - su debut como solista- y en el McCartney II. Adems, hay un elemento fundamental: la presencia de Nigel Godrich como productor -quien ha trabajado con  Radiohead, Travis y Beck-, cuya produccin no sobrecargada, ha logrado sonidos lozanos y agradables sin llegar a ser melifluos.    En Fine Line, tanto el piano como la batera crean un ambiente rock-pop festivo para una voz que suena joven a pesar de  sus 63 aos, de una de las estrofas sale una parte del ttulo del disco: \\"There is a long way between chaos and creation If you don't say wich one of these you're gonna choose...\\"(hay un largo camino entre el caos y la creacin si no dices cual de estos vas a escoger...). En How Kind Of You, el tpico, es la desesperanza total que logra superarse cuando uno encuentra a alguien con quien contar de verdad, unos loops de piano y guitarra completan el ambiente melanclico. La  acstica Jenny Wren, es considerada  \\"la hija\\" de Black Bird  con algunas pinceladas de Mother Nature's Son, ests dos ltimas del White Album de los Beatles,  los acordes son enriquecidos enormemente por el sonido clave de un duduk (una especie de clarinete), que le da otro matiz al estilo McCartniano del tema.     At The Mercy,  Too Much Rain, Follow Me y This Never Happened Before son los surcos ms convencionales, pero acaudalados con arreglos de cuerdas que les dan toques novedosos, destacando la ltima en mencin, por el sentimiento con que es cantado, el piano preciso y una letra simple pero muy del corazn, que hacen de ella una de sus mejores baladas de los ltimos 15 aos, \\"I'm very sure, this never happened to me before, I met you and now I'm sure this never happened before. Now I see this is the way it's supposed to be, I met you and now I see this is the way it should be\\" (Estoy muy seguro, esto nunca antes me haba pasado, te encontr y ahora estoy seguro que esto nunca antes sucedi. Ahora veo que esta es la manera  en que tena que darse, te encontr y ahora veo que esta es la manera en que sera).    Friends To Go, fue compuesta segn su autor, con una ayudadita de la \\"energa\\" de George Harrison, las principales notas son tocadas con una acstica, pero tambin se puede apreciar un rasgueo cortado de guitarra elctrica -que le da ms sustaine- y  por momentos una segunda voz muy oportuna. Lo ms rockero, lo encontramos en Promise To Your Girl, cuyo solo guitarresco  reemplaza muy bien al cantante, de esta lrica sale la otra parte del ttulo del disco: \\"Looking through the backyard of my life, time to sweep the fallen leaves away\\"(Mirando a travs del patio trasero de mi vida, tiempo para barrer las hojas que caen).    Pasemos a las canciones ms destacadas, en English Tea, el inicio con violn seguido de  un squito de cuerdas con una flauta al medio, acompaan de manera premeditada el homenaje con tonos sarcsticos que Macca hace de algunas tradiciones inglesas. A Certain Softness sobresale por sus arreglos, amn de una mezcla de bossa nova y bolero. Riding To Vanity Fair, que trata del fin de una amistad, es el ms sombro, con  unos sonidos de vasos de cristal que nos van transportando con la mente  a diversos lugares   que se van creando con el ambiente de la cancin. En el ltimo track, Anyway, l termina hablando de su \\"nuevo concepto\\" del amor: \\"If our love is strong enough, it may never end\\" (Si nuestro amor esbastante fuerte , es posible que nunca termine), luego de algunos segundos de silencio, asoma un hidden track instrumental de  3 minutos que muestra su lado menos convencional, con una perfecta suite, compuesta de melodas dismiles entre si, empalmadas magistralmente por la dupla McCartney-Godrich .    Para los coleccionistas, la edicin especial viene con un DVD que contiene un documental sobre cmo se hizo el lbum -donde se menciona que Godrich fue recomendado por George Martn y que en ocasiones tuvo que ser el crtico ms implacable de Sir Paul, cuando ste ltimo no lograba, por momentos, darle a sus canciones la trascendencia de su figura-,  un video de la performance en estudio del single hit Fine Line y unas imgenes con movimiento de cmara que muestran los trazos y  dibujos que se han incluido en el pequeo libro del disco.    Aqu tenemos un lbum que apuesta a ganador y que sale vencedor, gracias a la simbiosis Macca-Godrich, se nota la mano del joven productor, que ha revitalizado las canciones, hacindolas frescas y atractivas, con muestras de mucha juventud amalgamadas con el genio creativo y virtuoso del ex beatle, quien ha demostrado tener cuerda para rato, an cuando lo escuchemos cantar \\"When I'm Sixty Four\\".   Henry Flores R.  (...)
B000005YZM|3.0|When you're into British Sixties Rock, you know the Greatest Four: The Beatles, The Who, The Stones and (my personal faves) The Kinks.  Plus many more rhythm&blues and rock'n'roll outfits, such as Animals, Manfred Mann, Yardbirds. Diggin' to them you'll find the name Zombies on your way. And many many many audio-60s-philes could say you, that Zombies is one of the best rock bands of that era. And underrated one. <br />Album called \\"Odessey & Oracle\\" often presents in boring \\"Top 500 all-time albums\\"-listing in rock zines. Don't be fooled - if you buy this, you'll hear something really different from standard British ROCK sound. You'll hear the POP sound, much more similar to the late Beach Boys and McCartney-side of the Beatles, than to the Who or the Kinks. It's a pop music with no revolutionarity of rock and roll and even without \\"mind opening\\" of psychedelic freaks. <br />And the worst thing - melodies are good, but nowhere great enough to be covered... eehhh... by disco or punk band, for example. Early Zombies' single \\"She's Not There\\" greatly covered by UK Subs. And it's Zombies' only really hooking single. <br />I think of late Zombies just like about Beach Boys/Sgt Peppers pleasant, joyful, but not exciting followers. Not more.  <br />This is not album of All-time-top-200. Good, but not great in any point. Too polished and too predictable to break your mind apart.

B000A6T1JU|1.0|After almost a year of anticipation, the trumpeted \\"ultimate director's cut\\" of the beloved 1979 camp classic arrived - and it made George Lucas's belated Star Wars reeditions, with their already proverbially inane \\"Greedo shooting first\\" and \\"Hayden Christensen's head inserted over Sebastian Shaw\\" changes look like genuine improvements. <br /> <br />Walter Hill just managed to do what medicine previously thought unimaginable - he raped himself. He took a film loved by no less than four generations and murdered it, spat on it and desecrated its corpse. <br /> <br />The \\"ultimate cut\\" was turned into an imbecilic quasi-comic book film. Hill destroyed numerous legendary scenes by inserting awkward zooms, awkward cuts at pivotal moments, and - oh, heaven have mercy - freezes and transitions into \\"stylized\\" pseudo-comic book panels (actually seemingly made with the emboss filter of Photoshop), often complete with inane \\"thought bubble\\" comments. <br /> <br />Case in point - the scene in which the Warriors encounter the Furies. A powerful scene in which tension grows with every second, conveyed only through the actors' eyes and Barry de Vorzon's slowly creeping-up score. At least that is how it looked originally... because in the new version, at the second when the tension just began growing, the \\"new\\" film freezes and transforms into an idiotic comic book panel complete with - oh, God, why?!? - an imbecilic bubble comment stating \\"Holy sh..., the Baseball Furies!\\". That's how bad the new version is - and this isn't even the worst example. <br /> <br />He shattered the mystery of the ambient \\"Wonder Wheel\\" opening by inserting an absolutely unnecessary animate reference to Anabasis before it. And, worst of all, he obliterated the wonderful ending scene. You know it - it is the symbolic take showing the survivors  as they walk away from the memory of the night of horror towards the - perhaps hopeful - fresh dawn. I called this scene \\"the walk to nowhere - somewhere - everywhere\\". <br /> <br />In the new version, the walk is frozen after a few seconds and spliced into four idiotic comic book panels which then remain on screen. That single change is so wretchedly disgraceful that it defies belief. It is akin to taking, say, the closing scene of \\"The Godfather\\" and cutting it at the moment when Michael Corleone sits and thinks, rolling end credits at that moment rather than following it to show the legendary \\"new don\\" conclusion. <br /> <br />As the final insult, the DVD does not offer any worthy extras. There are some standard featurettes, but not much beyond that. Hill \\"does not believe in commentaries\\", apparently, so this is absent, but doesn't he believe in viewers' rights to watch deleted scenes, either? <br /> <br />It's true that most deleted scenes, in any films, on any DVD, are usually worthless and epitomize drivel - yet even truly bad ones are often included, since any viewer devoted to any film is always interested in seeing extra footage from it. I understand that Walter Hill may feel ashamed of those scenes and does not want them to be viewed even as a curiosity. I would not be surprised if some of them had not even been shot by him (particularly the infamous, awful day opening) - that would make his objection against their inclusion perfectly justified. However, considering that deleted scenes that do make it to existing DVDs as extra features very rarely represent all material that was cut from the film, and taking into account the typical running time of most rough cuts and workprints from late 70s, I would suspect that there was well over half an hour of alternate or additional footage shot - and that would be enough to choose some interesting snippets for the disc. And, Mister Hill... however bad even the worst deleted scene was, it would be practically impossible for it to be worse than the comic book insertions in the Ultimately Disgraceful Cut. <br /> <br />If there is anything worth having in this disc, it's thenew cover. It restores the original 1979 poster - the famous gang conclave in the park, with the tagline \\"They are the armies of the night\\". (The UK version has this cover, anyway. The US release apparently features an idiotic, oversaturated \\"Photochop\\" of a random scene from the film instead - identical to the previously available DVD's cover, but tinted in \\"angry\\" MTV red now...) <br /> <br />If that travesty is indeed representative of the concept that Walter Hill originally had in his mind in 1979, then I praise the studio board that changed it into the version that the audience knows and loves.

B0000524CY|5.0|PLOT:  The film begins at an archaeological dig in Iraq. One of the men working there is a 70-something year old priest named Father Lancaster Merrin (Max von Sydow.) Merrin has had a long and dark history. Something scares him more than anything. Merrin is getting ready to go back to America, but before leaving, he finds a statue at the excavation; a statue of a demon named Pazuzu. Merrin stares straight into the eyes of the statue and he feels a pain in the pit of his stomache, for he knows that one day he will have to face the devil again. The film then jumps to the other side of the world, in Georgetown (Washington D.C.) A famous actress named Chris MacNeil (Ellen Burstyn) lives there with her pre-teen daughter Regan (Linda Blair). Regan is a very loveable child, but suddenly she starts to show strange behavior. She starts swearing, urinating in front of people, acting violent. Doctors say that she has a rare nervous disorder, but ridolin doesn't help and her condition starts to get worse; much worse. When Chris has no one else to turn to, she goes to see Father Damien Karras (Jason Miller). She asks him if he would perform an exorcism on Regan, but he quickly turns her down because he needs approval from the Catholic Church; not to mention he has his own inner demons to deal with. He finally agrees to review Regan's condition. With the evidence he can collect, he may be able to get approval from the Church. Karras, a psychiatrist as well as a priest, feels that there is probably a mental explanation for Regan's condition. He soon realizes that he is up against the devil himself.<br /><br />COMMENTS:  In my honest opinion, this is the scariest film of all time. I had the pleasure of seeing this film in the theater when it was re-released in 2000, and it scared the hell out of me. William Friedkin's directorial style was brilliant. The film also boasts a fine cast with great acting. William Peter Blatty wrote the screenplay based on his own 1971 novel, and it's fantastic. Not only is this a great horror film, it's a great character study. We see that both Merrin and Karras are men of God, but they are flawed characters. Merrin has had a run-in with the devil before and he's scared to death of him. He knows that he has an on-going fight with him. Karras has his own insecurities as well; he begins to doubt his faith and constantly blaims himself for the death of his mother. Blatty's novel was actually inspired by a true story. A 13-year-old boy from Mt. Rainier, Maryland named Robbie was possessed by a demon in 1949. Robbie was able to make his bed shake without touching it, as well as move several other objects without physical contact. The boy also said blasphemous things in a diabolical voice. The local cardinal authorized an exorcism. The exorcism process lasted for 2 months. The demon within finally recognized the presence of St. Michael and was expelled from Robbie's body forever. Robbie remembered nothing of the possession afterwards, except the vision of St. Michael. The film was eventually followed by 2 inferior sequels: \\"Exorcist II: The Heretic\\" (1977) and \\"The Exorcist III\\" (1990); the latter was based on William Peter Blatty's sequel novel \\"Legion\\" (1983). 2 prequels also followed: \\"Exorcist: The Beginning\\" (2004) and it's alternate version \\"Dominion: Prequel To The Exorcist\\" (2005); the latter was released straight to DVD. This new DVD presents the film in its original widescreen theatrical ratio. This updated version has extra scenes not seen in the original 1973 release. It also features commentary by William Friedkin, bios and facts, and the theatrical trailer. I would recommend this film to anybody. It is a timeless classic.c. Merrin has had a run-in with the devil before and he's scared to death of him. He knows that he has an on-going fight with him. Karras has his own insecurities as well; he begins to doubt his faith and constantly blaims himself for the death of his mother. Blatty's novel was actually inspired by a true story. B0002KVULG|3.0|I love Vampires. I do, I love them. In particular, I love the story of Dracula as told (and so often re-told in Hollywood) by Bram Stoker. I'd never heard of this film version of the story before, and so I ordered it, surprised to see such a cast roster in a movie that, from my standpoint, has been lost to time and glossier adaptations. Having watched it, I'm happy to say that this isn't a DVD I'll be giving away. It's not perfect (by a long shot), but it is quite good. <br /> <br />You know the story, mysterious European Count Dracula (Langella) comes to England and the undead body count starts to rise. Enter Van Helsing (Olivier) and Johnathan Harker, hell-bent on avenging their dead and saving their nearly-undead. <br /> <br />Direction here is stylish and slick, a monochromatic kind of gothicness with the odd splash of colour to keep our visual interest. It's a ploy that works well, and director John Badham wisely keeps away, for the most part, from poor special effects, allowing instead the romantic and hypnotic elements of the Dracula figure to create the tension. Langella's excellent as the vampire equivalent of Rudolf Valentino, he emanates a magnetism and charisma that, in less-capable hands, would simply have looked camp. Similarly, Kate Nelligan's portrayal of Lucy is excellent, she imbues the heroine with a lot more life and spirit than Winona Ryder or Frances Dade, and comes across as an independent and all the more sympathetic heroine, as opposed to some helpless 19th century woman who couldn't help herself. <br /> <br />In fact, all of the supporting cast, save an awkward turn by Jan Francis as Mina Van Helsing, is accomplished and good.  <br /> <br />The only real problems come with the script and storyline. Parts of Stoker's original novel have been cannibalised, rewritten or left out altogether, and the ending, while not particularly bad, is not rewarding enough for a movie of this scope. Some of the dialogue feels particularly clunky and trite, and while the solid, talented cast does their best with it, it can't help but affect the storyline in negative ways. <br /> <br />Still, for the beautiful direction and really rather excellent performances from the leads, this 1979 retelling of Dracula is highly recommended for fans of the story, and is still a very entertaining movie for the public at large.

0790744295|3.0|\\"Creepshow\\" is not a movie that will ever win any awards. It's a campy, comical collection of schlock-horror and B-movie inspired tales of zombies and alien retribution, and, although directed by the talented Geroge Romero and written by the talented Stephen King, somehow falls short of its intended mark, instead languishing in camp excessiveness. <br /> <br />There are five mimi-movies that comprise 'Creepshow', and the three of them show huge promise - they could be extended into full screenplays and remain successful, as tales. \\"Father's Day\\" starring Viveca Lindfors, \\"Something to tide you over\\" with Leslie Nielsen and a very young Ted Danson, and \\"They're creeping up on you\\" with E.G, Marshall are all very fine ideas, but, as with the two slightly weaker offerings - \\"The lonesome death of Jordy Verrill\\" and \\"The Crate\\", lose whatever horror they might have contained to some rotten dialogue and lousy special effects.  <br /> <br />These problems, however, far from removing all of the movie's worth, create a worthiness of their own, in that \\"Creepshow\\" is the \\"Mommie Dearest\\" of the horror genre. It's OTT and colourful, with no thought given to consistency or dialogue, so instead of a chilling and scary collection of short films, what we're left with is a funny, crazy ride on the lighter side of horror. \\"I... want... my... Caaaake, Bedelia!\\" is surely the \\"No Wire Hangers, Ever!\\" of Creepshow, and in \\"The lonesome death of Jordy Verrill\\", Stephen King as the titular Jordy seems to understand that this couldn't possibly be played for anything other than weird laughs. <br /> <br />Overall, for campy fun, I'd give the movie 4 stars. The DVD conversion, sadly, is awful - dirty and scratchy with pretty pathetic mono sound - so it loses another star for this.

B000002GJH|5.0|A musical collaboration by Chris Cornell, Jeff Ament, Stone Gossard, Eddie Vedder, Matt Cameron and Mike McCready. <br /> <br />(former) Members of: <br />- Soundgarden (Cornell, Cameron) <br />- Green River & Mother Love Bone (Gossard, Ament) <br />- Pearl Jam (Vedder, McCready, Gossard, Ament, Cameron) <br />- Mad Season (McCready) <br /> <br />A guaranteed hit, one could say.  <br /> <br />After the untimely death of MotherLoveBone frontman Andrew Wood, singer/songwriter Chris Cornell penned a few songs in tribute to his friend and fellow Seattle musician, which were \\"Reach Down\\" and \\"Say Hello 2 Heaven.\\" He decided to approach Stone Gossard and Jeff Ament, Andy's friends and bandmates with the new material and then the project really started to take off. <br />  <br />At the time, Soundgarden had yet to become superstars and Cornell recruited his Soundgarden compatriot Matt Cameron for this project who coincidentally at that time was working with Gossard, Ament and a new guy on the block, one Mike McCready. To finish the line-up they auditioned a potential frontman, San Diego surfer boy: Eddie Vedder. Rick Parasher was reeled in to do production duties and off they went. <br /> <br />The first track on the cd is the Cornell penned \\"Say Hello 2 Heaven\\". An amazing piece of musical balance. Good music, great lyrics and even better vocals. A fine choice for an opening track. <br /> <br />Next is \\"Reach Down\\", which shows the group's potential of playing heavier music than just (semi-)acoustic ballads. In the middle of the song is an extensive instrumental placed, which lasts for over 3,5 minutes. <br /> <br />\\"Hunger Strike\\", the bands first single, might very well be the cd's best song. For anyone who would like to hear what a combination of PJ & Soundgarden sounds like, check it out! Vedder and Cornell share vocal duties and both sound excellent. Especially when later in the song when they follow each other up. <br /> <br />\\"Pushin Forward Back\\", the cd's 4th song is yet again a musical masterpiece, even though I personally dont really like Cornell's lyrics to this song. The music is great and it justs has this energetic vibe to it. <br /> <br />\\"Call me a Dog\\" slows you down again, giving you a moment to recover from the previous songs' activity. McCready's guitar solo near the end of the song is well crafted and suits the song very well. And that's a feat that a lot of musicians seem to forget these days... a solo has to has a function.  <br /> <br />\\"Times of Trouble\\" continues the mellow state of things started by the previous song. A pretty good song, especially the chorus. The piano could have been left out of you ask me, but I assume the producer-played instrument has some sort of function. <br /> <br />\\"Wooden Jesus\\" starts of with 30 seconds of fine drumming & percussion, but the rest of the song is a bit too plain for my taste. The guitar solo, the music and the singing just dont sound as good as the rest of the album. Lyrics make up for some of the lesser aspects of the song, but I still think this is the weakest song by Temple of the Dog. <br /> <br />\\"Your Savior\\" picks up where 'pushing forward back' ended in terms of energetical vibe. It is still pretty easy going at times, but the electric guitar takes on more of a central role in this song. Decent song. <br /> <br />\\"Four Walled World\\" is an awesome song. When first listening to the cd I was afraid that after the first 5 songs they had used up most of their chemistry, but listening to FWW simply is a pleasure.  <br /> <br />Last, but not least, \\"All Night Thing\\" is the perfect closer for this album. Makes you think about all you've heard again. <br /> <br />All in all a very good album, just missing the 'masterpiece' classification in my opinion, due to 2 or 3 lesser songs. <br /> <br />A sidenote to all this, is that even though Eddie Vedder is credited for singing backup vocals on 3 songs on this album but, aside from his co-lead vocals on \\"Hunger Strike\\", isnt really noticable throughout the songs. <br /> <br />\\"I want to show you something, like joy inside my heart  <br />Seems I been living in the Temple Of The Dog  <br />Where would I live if I were a man of golden words  <br />Or would I live at all\\" - Andy Wood, \\"Man of Golden Words\\"
B000002G0P|5.0|Never really caring for their first two albums, I'm not sure why I picked this CD up years ago.  But I immediately recognized that this was something different. 1401206905|5.0|In 1986, Frank Miller sent a ripple through the comic book industry with the release of \\"Batman: The Dark Knight Returns.\\"  In this, his follow-up, Miller opted to go from telling of Batman's 'ending' to his beginning.  With artist David Mazzuchelli on board and the use of a very specific color palette, the results are mesmerizing.  In a very concise story that features nearly no \\"Rogues Gallery\\" villains, we see young Bruce Wayne battling a corrput police force, as well as waging war on organized crime as he figures out who he is underneath it all and becomes The Batman.  Mazzuchelli's Bruce Wayne is identical to a young Gregory Peck - one wonders how Peck might have portrayed him, given the opportunity.   <br /> <br />The beauty of Miller's work, both here and elsewhere, is that his writing style gives the world his characters inhabit a realistic edge.  This is true here.  All of the characters are deeply flawed, and at times many of them become less than savory for a brief period.  But they all feel human, and fit into the fabric of what we see and read here. Bruce Wayne is indeed the central character, and his path is rife with trial and error as he reaches that point of becoming Batman, and even after.  Jim Gordon was previously never as fleshed out in the comics as he is here.  Perhaps the next Batman movie will give him more story, because he's a great character.  He's used well by Miller throughout this work. <br /> <br />If the above plot description brings to mind the second and third act of Batman Begins, that's because the filmmakers admit to having been influenced heavily by this work.  Even the most casual Batman fan will enjoy this story, especially in this excellent edition.
B000002KZ6|4.0|This is definitely the Talking Heads' best album without Brian Eno.  It's by far their most accessible, but also quite inventive.  Losing Eno, this group could easily have retrogressed into the mode of producing cheap, unimaginative imitations of the sound he previously created for them -- enjoying Top-40 success but committing musical suicide.  This, incidentally, is precisely what DEVO did after Brain parted company with them (and to a slightly lesser extent, David Bowie in the mid-80s).  The Heads, on the other hand, had in David Byrne a near-equal to Eno (some would say protege and not be far off the mark) in studio experimentation and vision.  Byrne collaborated with Eno a few years before on the excellent \\"My Life in the Bush of Ghosts\\" and with this album began to show that the relationship was time well spent.

LOST, but this album from the mid 90s is classic.

B000B0WODA|5.0|Only few bands can make two awesome records in such a short time just like Fran Ferdinand did. Maybe The Strokes, but that's it. Franz Ferdinand wrapped up an excellent second album, blending their usual pop-rock tracks with some surprisingly catchy ballads. <br />\\"The Fallen\\" introduces the main mood of the record with a clever use of the two guitars, running on and cooperating with the vocals, always pleasant, just like happens in the second track \\"Do You Want To\\", the first single came out and probably the most involving song of this LP.  <br />Slightly nervous, \\"This Boy\\" is an example of high-energy rock without losing agreeability. Then comes track 4 \\"Walk Away\\", the first amazing ballad, dealing with  acoustic guitars and polished vocals.  <br />The following song (\\"Evil and a Heathen\\")it's a tribute to vintage rock made with energy and style. There comes \\"You're The Reason I'm Leaving\\", a catchy chorus with a background of poignant music.  <br />Track 7 is \\"Eleanor Put Your Boots On\\", a tribute to The Beatles so well made that one could easily think that it's a cover or something like that... but it's not. This ballad represents clearly an artistic growth from the band.  <br />The following song it's \\"Well That Was Easy\\", dealing with surprising changes of rhythm and an ironic text. Here comes \\"What You Meant\\", despite of the title not very meaningful but still pleasant, especially one of the last guitar riffs.  <br />Seems to hear some Keith Richards riffs with a ubiquitous bass and an hard-working voice on \\"I'm Your Villain\\", probably the most complete song of the record, a new \\"manifesto\\" of Franz Ferdinand music.  <br />The following track \\"You Could Have It So Much Better\\" deals with aggressive vocals, fast rhythm and it's perfect because after it comes the third and final ballad, \\"Fade Together\\", which brings a totally different mood, with a polite piano on a base of soft and gentle instruments flourishing behind some excellent vocals... nothing more vintage than this! <br />The ending track (\\"Outsiders\\") brings again some of the precedent energy, with catchy guitars and some far-west harmonics closing the album in a most awesome way. <br /> <br />This it Their music. Do not be satisfied with modern rock, because You Could Have It So Much Better...with Franz Ferdinand!

B000AL730O|5.0|McCartney is well known as not only one of the world's finest songwriters for his work with the Beatles, but also, sadly, as one of the most twee, self-indulgent and horribly cheesy solo artists for almost all of his work that followed. The occasional good song on a solo album tended to be overshadowed by the chirpy, thumbs-aloft, mullet-wearing purveyor of the naffest songs imaginable.<br /><br />So it was with delight that I listened to this album. There isn't a bad song on it, although many are pretty average. One or two of them are good enough to justify buying the album alone. What really makes this album stand out is the outstanding production: McCartney has found someone who knows how to bring out the best in him.<br /><br />You can almost hear the battle on record: McCartney occasionally straying too close to the candle, trying to add in a couple of cheesy \\"whoo-hoos\\" or a corny lyric, while the producer swifly veers him away from the cheese and keeps the songs tight, meaningful and without too much self-indulgence. The songs shine as a result. There are unapologetically Beatle-y moments that sound natural, not some bad attempt to recapture past glories. McCartney's over-cosy voice is tempered by some sparse, minor-key and sometimes darn spooky instrumentation that echoes his experimental best work of 40 years before.<br /><br />If I were Sir Paul, I'd choose the one good song on each of my prior solo albums, re-record them with this guy to make one classic double album, and then burn all my older solo work.<br /><br />Here is finally a McCartney solo album with only 2 or 3 seconds of cringing-at-cheese to deal with, and the rest of the time a firm hand seems to have veered him back towards adding to, not insulting, his legacy.
B0007GAERG|4.0|To say that Mariah was a has-been after her critically slammed \\"Charmbracelet,\\" is untrue. B000AXSN5G|5.0|It's hard to be objective about new material when you're a Neil Young fan.  However, I am not in love with all of his work.  Prairie Wind is a great effort and the finished material is very well done.  Someone described \\"Greendale\\" as a \\"demo tape\\" that became a CD.  Greendale is an excellent piece of work as well and I cannot argue the \\"rough around the edges\\" sound but you have to consider how Neil \\"hears\\" his work re-produced.  Crazy Horse (Greendale) vs. basically The International Harvesters (Prairie Wind) are a long way apart in concept and sound.  These songs are heartfelt and very personal in nature, revealing things about Neil's life that have rarely gone beyond the private circle of his family and friends.  When he has said \\"I heard Emmy Lou's voice or, Ben Keith's steel guitar when I wrote these songs\\", we are listening to what must be his replication of that sound on the finished product.  Many of Neil's albums must be heard several times and more frequently than not, they will grow on you.  Prairie Wind is one of these.  I am amazed at Neil's marketing skills to reach out to the listener with a DVD of the work being filmed live during the recording sessions.  The interaction between Neil, his friend's and the musicians are a visual testimony to just how important the music really is to him.  I am certain that the Nashville concert film with these performances, when it is released, will be outstanding as well.  So, I rate Prairie Wind as one of the best pieces of Neil's work that I have.  And, I basically have all of his releases.

Wonka was some what of a recluse with a less than delightful childhood, so it would make sense that he would be a somewhat akward character, laking in strong social skills. I feel that Burton was the perfect person to bring Dahl's classic book to film, with his ability to bring imagination into reality.  <br />I must admit, choosing Depp for the part of Wonka was a little difficult for me to imagine at first, but he gave an excelent performance. I loved seeing Johnny Depp and Freddie Highmore(Charlie) work together again; they were wonderful in \\"Finding Deverland\\". Freddie is a wonderful little actor, I would like to see his carreer carry on into adulthood. <br /> Tim Burton, along with the acting skills of Johnny Depp, succeeded in creating a wonderful and unique film that I feel relates more to the original Dahl story. Dahl himself would've enjoyed it, since he himself disapproved of the 1971 film. I wish people could stop comparing \\"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory\\" to the 71' film, so that they can see it for the interesting, delightful, inspiring film that it is.

B000AYEIZY|5.0|Let's get one thing straight from the start: this is not the same Cream as the band that broke up 37 years ago.  Yes, it's the same three guys, but those almost-four decades have made their mark.  The good news is that, overall, it's a pretty good mark.   <br /> <br />On the downside, Jack Bruce's voice has lost some of it's range and power, and Ginger Baker sounds like what he is: a senior citizen trying to remind people what he once could do.  At times he's successful in that attempt, and at others he falls short.  The competitive spark that fired Cream's sound has fizzled.  The sound of Bruce and Clapton seemingly battling for dominance of the band's lead is no more. <br /> <br />In its place, though, is the sound of three musicians playing together, and doing it extraordinarily well.  Clapton does some of his best playing in years here, and Jack Bruce's playing still puts him in the top ranks of bass players.  As you can see from the list of songs, they've hit every period of Cream's (brief) history.  The arrangements are tight and crisp, and the solos are superb.  In particular, the arrangements of \\"White Room\\" and \\"Badge\\"(the original recordings of which have never been recreated well on stage) are outstanding. <br /> <br />Other reviewers will doubtless provide lists of the best tracks on the album, and every list will differ.  I'll settle for saying that the scorching work on \\"Stormy Monday\\" is, by itself, well worth the cost of the album. <br /> <br />Unlike other bands from the Sixties that have become oldies acts or parodies of themselves, Cream came back full blast.  This album is a pure delight.  As much as I normally avoid music DVDs, the knowledge that the companion DVD to this collection contains different versions of these songs (it was, after all, a four night stand) has me hustling over to check it out.

B0009SOFFY|5.0|Iggy Pop and his Stooges are one of the great underrated classics of rock n' roll history. We owe this band so much and yet give them such little attention even on VH1 Classic (though VH1 has at least put the band on its 100 Greatest Artists Of Hard Rock list), but those who truly love rock music and what it can do will eventually come across the snarling music contained in \\"The Stooges\\" and \\"Fun House,\\" not to mention the timeless third album \\"Raw Power.\\" Though \\"Raw Power\\" received a shining, brutally loud remix a couple of years ago, the first Stooges albums are barely getting the deserved special editions aficionados and rock enthusiasts have been waiting for. Now \\"Fun House\\" really comes alive with remastered sound that truly exposes the intensity and fire Iggy Pop let loose on the world. The story goes that in 1967 Iggy caught a Doors show and was so impressed by Jim Morrison that he decided to invent his own brand of shock rock theatrics, this of course resulted in being one of the most memorable acts hard rock has ever produced. The sound and attitude of the Stooges is everywhere, especially in bands like Marilyn Manson, Guns N' Roses, Stone Temple Pilots, Nirvana, Green Day, R.E.M., The Vines, The Hives, The White Stripes etc. etc. etc. The Punk movement claimed Iggy as its godfather and artists like Blondie and The Sex Pistols payed homage to this, one of their great heroes. \\"Fun House\\" embodies all that made The Stooges great, it's a mix of raw sound with wild theatrics, images. Think of William S. Burroughs framed by Nine Inch Nails (Iggy is in fact a Burroughs fan recorded with the legendary beat writer before he died). The songs have catchy, heavy hooks and a seductive, animalistic air as in \\"Down On The Street,\\" a crawling jam that can be the soundtrack for a night of lust and fun. \\"T.V. Eye\\" is the wildness of Iggy and The Stooges caught on tape with it's primal screams and burning guitar licks. \\"Loose\\" is an interesting number that progresses from chaos to an almost poppy chorus. \\"L.A. Blues\\" is pure expressionism while \\"1970\\" has that anthemic feel of all great Punk (and this was BEFORE the genre even existed). \\"Fun House\\" is in a sense a packaging of all the craziness, sex and musical creativity evident in American music. It feels as if the Stooges took all of America's most notable genres like blues, jazz and rock n' roll and filtered it through their bold, excess-drenched concepts. Here is music that is up to the level of the legend. Iggy Pop of course garnered fame cutting himself with glass on stage and even having audience members perform oral sex on him during shows, but the music personifies completely the wild theatrics and even the more intellectual ideas behind the shock and provocation. Like all great rock \\"Fun House\\" stands up to the best music hard rock bands have offered us in the past few years. Listen to The Stooges and you realize Disturbed, Staind and Godsmack are pretty much just p---y music.
B0006HXXBA|5.0|It's a good time to release \\"Enemy of God,\\" because heavy metal is now quite popular; but, since it's so popular, Kreator also have some competition. Bands like Lamb of God and Shadows Fall have cropped up and have been given the label \\"modern thrash,\\" but, when you listen to \\"Enemy of God,\\" you'll realize there's nothing like the real thing (true thrash!)<br /><br />After going through an experimental phase, thrash metal titans Kreator have returned to form with their twelfth album. And while this is their thrashiest album in years, \\"Enemy of God\\" also incorporates some melodic death metal into the mix, because singer Miland Petrozza's vocals sort of sound like Devin Townsend's (of Strapping Young Lad). The vocals aren't great, because singer Miland sounds somewhat silly at times. Fortunately, however, there's enough whiplash guitar shredding to make up for it. The guitars are so fast and catchy, they echo prime `80's thrash, like Slayer.<br /><br />The album begins with a bang; track one, the title song, shoots out of the gate with blindingly fast riffs. And from there on, it almost never lets up. Even when things slow down, like for track six, they eventually speed up to at least a moderately fast chug. \\"Suicide Terrorist\\" sounds almost Priest-y, with fast, explosive riffs and three guitar solos, and \\"World Anarchy\\" has a rocketing beat, with almost careening guitar work. Other highlights include the creepy, dark lyrics (like \\"All I see is mothers dragging children to the grave\\") of \\"Impossible Brutality,\\" the great drum work and extended guitar solo on \\"Voices of the Dead,\\" track eight's catchy, chugging riffs, and on \\"Dying Race Apocalypse,\\" they take a cue from Sepultura by including an acoustic guitar intro (before the buzzsaw guitars and lightning fast double bass drums kick in).<br /><br />All in all, Kreator have created a true thrash masterpiece. And it is easily the best (and maybe the only) true thrash release of 2005. Have the leaders returned? No. The MASTERS have returned..
B00005JKG7|4.0|I originally saw \\"The Fog\\" in the theater, and remember being frightened in multiple places. John Carpenter managed to make a low budget picture scary using minimum special effects and a whole lot of fog. While fog has been used in other movies (I remember the attack of the werewolf in \\"Silver Bullet,\\" where the werewolf attacked from the fog around his pursuers' feet), it was pervasive and thick, and the attacks came suddenly from the dense fog and yet the fog cleared enough to let you see the action.<br /><br />Antonio Bay is a small seaside town with a past. The past includes allowing a group of sailors to die on their ship. We know that this is a horror movie, and the dead rarely rest easy in their graves, particularly watery graves. When an eerie dense fog rolls over a ship, and there are thumps and bumps and suddenly the ship is unmanned, we know there is something wrong with the fog.<br /><br />We can also guess the fog will not stay out to see. As the intensity in the movie builds we see the fog roll in and the fog roll out, accompanying a great cast. John Houseman is spooky beach narrator Mr. Machen, sending chills through his audience as easily as he did his classes in \\"The Paper Chase.\\" Janet Leigh is a town mover and shaker Kathy Williams and her indignation quickly changes to fear as she realizes the fog is outside her control and her experience. Jamie Lee Curtis is free spirit Elizabeth Solley, who seems to be a hands breadth from disaster for most of the movie. Hal Holbrook is Father Malone, a priest with psychological issues who feels like a martyr, intended or otherwise, from the time we first meet him. Tom Atkins plays Nick Castle, who fortunately takes into stride that evil ghosts are wandering around town with bad intent. Even John Carpenter makes an appearance.<br /><br />With all this talent, what more can you ask? How about Adrienne Barbeau as sultry Stevie Wayne, the voice of the local radio station who manages to put movie-goers into the right frame of mind as the fog rolls over the town and Stevie becomes an inadvertent Cassandra, heard only by those of us watching the movie. Ultimately I was clinging to the edge of my seat as Stevie Wayne tried to stay one step ahead of the fog and its evil.<br /><br />John Carpenter made \\"The Fog\\" in the style of horror movies of old. The movie relies on what you can barely see and the ever-present fog to build atmosphere rather than splattering blood and organs. The tension as the fog rolls into town and the bizarre events unroll builds until you think something has to happen, and John Carpenter keeps you guessing as to if and when throughout. Perhaps the best tension of all is when the fog rolls into Stevie Wayne's radio station and she frantically and fearfully tries her best to defend herself from the unknown.<br /><br />\\"The Fog\\" has its flaws, as do most movies of this type. However, I somehow manage to overlook them each time I watch because I get caught up in the characters and the story. There are few enough horror movies that are made in the style of \\"The Fog,\\" and when one is made that makes you want to watch the movie a second or third time, you know it is a winner.o the right frame of mind as the fog rolls over the town and Stevie becomes an inadvertent Cassandra, heard only by those of us watching the movie. Ultimately I was clinging to the edge of my seat as Stevie Wayne tried to stay one step ahead of the fog and its evil.  <br /> <br />John Carpenter made \\"The Fog\\" in the style of horror movies of old. The movie relies on what you can barely see and the ever-present fog to build atmosphere rather than splattering blood and organs. The tension as the fog rolls into town and the bizarre events unroll builds until you think something has to happen, and John Carpenter keeps you guessing as to if and when throughout. Perhaps the best tension of all is when the fog rolls into Stevie Wayne's radio station and she frantically and fearfully tries her best to defend herself from the unknown.  <br /> <br />\\"The Fog\\" has its flaws, as do most movies of this type. There are few enough horror movies that are made in the style of \\"The Fog,\\" and when one is made that makes you want to watch the movie a second or third time, you know it is a winner. <br />

1594481784|4.0|Nick Hornby gives music and romance a philosophical spin in \\"High Fidelity,\\" the funny, rueful book about men, music, and modern love. While occasionally his lead character's \\"top five\\" lists can be a little annoying, this is a charmingly original, wry and thoughtful novel - an offbeat romance for our time.<br /><br />Rob owns a little music shop in London, which is a good thing because he is musically obsessed -- pop music, he claims, makes him fall in love. But even pop music can't heal his heart when his longtime girlfriend Laura breaks up and moves out. What's worse, Rob has no idea WHY she broke up with him, and he feels mixed feelings about losing her (he cares about her) and her musical tastes (bad).<br /><br />He immerses himself in his rickety business with his weirdo employees -- these guys alone are worth checking out the book for. He dates a folk singer. He learns that Laura is now involved with the repulsive guy upstairs. And finally, he assesses his past sex life and romances (the top five, specifically), getting a bit of insight into what Laura's problem with him might be: He's stuck in his mid-teens.<br /><br />Thirty-five is kind of old to start growing up. But like many real people, Rob learns that it's change or die -- in his case, alone and surrounded by records. \\"High Fidelity\\" is a nice blend of musical/movie memoir, love story and belated-coming-of-age tale. It's kind of geeky and pokes fun at itself, but therein lies its charm.<br /><br />Hornby writes a nice, breezy kind of prose, peppered with plenty of pop culture and musical references. Not to mention the top five lists: Top Five Episodes of Cheers. Best Side One Track Ones Of All Time. Top Five Bands or Musicians Who Will Have To Be Shot Come the Musical Revolution. At times the pop culture name-dropping gets a bit tiresome, but it mostly underlines how quirky and mildly obsessive Rob can be.<br /><br />And oh, he can be quirky. He can also be a self-centered jerk, and a bit confused and clueless to boot. Hornby's alter ego is likable for his flaws, and somehow manages to shed a little light on how men think. Good backup comes in his clerks Barry and Dick, who are just as geekily eccentric about music and lists as Rob is.<br /><br />Nick Hornby's \\"High Fidelity\\" is an excellent slice of Brit-lit -- it's quirky, wry, insightful, and a bit obsessed with good music. Definitely a must-read.d a bit confused and clueless to boot. Hornby's alter ego is likable for his flaws, and somehow manages to shed a little light on how men think. Good backup comes in his clerks Barry and Dick, who are just as geekily eccentric about music and lists as Rob is.  <br />  <br />Nick Hornby's \\"High Fidelity\\" is an excellent slice of Brit-lit -- it's quirky, wry, insightful, and a bit obsessed with good music. Definitely a must-read.
